Job Description Senior Survey Statistician Apply Now Position Description Mathematica is a nationally recognized research organization that conducts social policy studies on health care, disability, education, welfare, nutrition, and related topics. Our mission is to improve public well-being by bringing the highest standards of quality, objectivity, and excellence to bear on the work we do for our clients, which include federal, state, and local government agencies, as well as private foundations. We currently have an opening for a senior survey statistician to oversee our statistical design, implementation, and analysis activities for large-scale or complex data collection studies. The senior survey statistician must possess expertise in survey sampling and weighting, strong oral and written communication skills, the ability to work in an interdisciplinary team, and familiarity with statistical software. This position requires strong project and business development leadership skills. We are especially interested in individuals with expertise in RDD and ABS sampling, variance estimation for complex sample survey data, nonresponse bias analysis, imputation, survey research methodology (survey paradata, total survey error, and adaptive survey design), data linkage, data disclosure avoidance, and small area estimation. Our projects use interdisciplinary teams made up of subject matter specialists, statisticians, survey researchers, and software engineers. We offer our employees a stimulating, team-oriented work environment, competitive salaries, and a comprehensive benefits package, as well as the advantages of employee ownership. We provide generous paid time off and an on-site fitness center. Position Requirements PhD in statistics or related field plus five years of work experience in statistics including at least three years in a similar work environment. A combination of equivalent education and work experience may be substituted for the above requirements Expertise in sample design and weighting Strong oral and written communication skills Strong project and business development leadership skills Knowledge and/or experience in the areas of survey sampling (including RDD and ABS), weighting, variance estimation for complex sample survey data, imputation, survey research methodology (especially on survey paradata, total survey error, and adaptive survey design), data linkage, and data disclosure avoidance is desirable Knowledge and experience with statistical software Please submit a cover letter and resume and be sure to include your salary requirements. Please also submit a 1-page statement of career goals and accomplishments, and arrange for three letters of reference to be sent directly to Dr. Leiser at leiser@umich.edu . Job Summary The Leiser lab in the Department of Molecular and Integrative Physiology has 1-2 postdoctoral positions available for scientists interested in studying the biology of aging.   Projects include studying cell non-autonomous signaling that leads to improved health and longevity, elucidating the mechanism of a new “longevity” protein that lies downstream of multiple longevity pathways, and studying a negative feedback pathway that uses post-translational modification to regulate stress resistance and longevity.  Other projects studying the role of stress response/stress resistance in aging are also available.  Projects can involve nematode biology, tissue culture, and/or mouse studies.  US permanent residents eligible for NIH training grants preferred. Responsibilities* The primary responsibility of the position is to help design and manage research projects in line with the goals of the laboratory.  These projects may involve multiple organisms (nematodes, tissue culture, mice) and many approaches, but will ultimately center on the biology of aging.  Fellows are expected to be independent, self-motivated, and experienced, and should have significant expertise and technical skills.  Other roles include training and supervising undergraduate researchers, participating in research/data analysis, suggesting future improvements in data measurement, and preparation of presentations/manuscripts. Must be able to work independently on collection of data and analysis of research results.  Previous expertise in the biology of aging is not required, but is encouraged. Required Qualifications* Ph.D. in related field.  Comfort working both independently and collaboratively, a scientific background, and the desire and flexibility to accommodate animal research. Excellent organizational skills are a must.  Previous experience with C. elegans genetics, molecular biology, and/or mouse research will receive higher consideration. All biological data pertinent to collections and preservation are recorded. Assists in maintenance of various collections used in connection with day-to-day research activities.
